title: To the Ends of the Earth
objective: Conclude Acts by tracing Paul's trials, voyage, shipwreck, and final gospel witness in Rome.

required_passages.text: Paul testified before Felix, Festus, and Agrippa... 'I stand here testifying... saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would come to pass: that the Christ must suffer and... rise from the dead.' ... he appealed to Caesar... endured storm and shipwreck... in Rome he proclaimed the kingdom of God and taught about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.

segments.audio_script: Acts ends with a prisoner preacher carrying the gospel to Rome. Today we see trials, storms, and unstoppable witness.

Listen to Acts 24 through 28. Paul defended the faith before governors Felix and Festus and before King Agrippa, insisting he proclaimed only what Moses and the prophets foretold: Messiah's suffering and resurrection. To avoid unjust transfer, Paul appealed to Caesar. On the voyage to Rome, a violent storm struck. Paul encouraged all aboard with God's promise that lives would be spared though the ship would be lost. They were shipwrecked on Malta, where Paul ministered with signs and healing. Finally arriving in Rome, Paul met Jewish leaders and explained the kingdom of God from Moses and the Prophets, persuading some while others disbelieved. Acts closes with Paul under house arrest, proclaiming Jesus Christ with all boldness and without hindrance.
Rome was the empire's center. Reaching Rome symbolizes the gospel's advance to the nations. Luke leaves Paul's final outcome unstated, focusing instead on the unhindered word.

Acts closes open-ended to show the mission continues through the church. Political trials become evangelistic opportunities. Providence governs storms and courts alike. The kingdom message remains rooted in Scripture and centered on Jesus' death and resurrection. 'Without hindrance' summarizes God's unstoppable mission.

Key themes include faithful legal defense, scriptural fulfillment, resurrection proclamation, perseverance in hardship, providence in danger, mission to imperial centers, and unhindered gospel advance.
Reflect on this: Do you view constraints as barriers or mission fields? Where is God calling you to proclaim Christ with boldness right now?
Acts ends with the gospel advancing in Rome, and the mission continues through us today. Next we move into Pauline Epistles.
